appendix.title: Recovering Clusters to a Healthy State
appendix.para: If one node in your cluster refuses to rejoin the cluster, it is most likely that the node has not been shut down cleanly. This can either be due to manual intervention or because the node has been fenced (shut down) by the &stonith; mechanism of the cluster, to protect the integrity of data in case of a split-brain scenario.

sect1.title: Symptoms of a Degraded &contrnode; Cluster
sect1.para: The following incidents may occur if a &contrnode; in your cluster has been shut down in an unclean state:

listitem.para: A VM reboots although the &cloud; administrator did not trigger this action.
One of the &contrnode; in the &crow; &wi; is in status Problem, signified by a red dot next to the node.
The &hawk; &wi; stops responding on one of the &contrnode;s, while it is still responding on the others.
The SSH connection to one of the &contrnode;s freezes.
The &ostack; components stop responding for a short while.

If you have a 2-node cluster with the option set to Automatic, you need to remove the block file that is created on a node during start of the cluster service:

The block file avoids &stonith; deathmatches for 2-node clusters (where each node kills the other one, resulting in both nodes rebooting all the time). When &corosync; shuts down cleanly, the block file is automatically removed. Otherwise the block file is still present and prevents the cluster service from (re-)starting on that node.
An alternative way to bypass the block file is to start the cluster service on the cluster node before making the node reconnect to Crowbar in the next section (see ):

sect1.title: Recovering From an Unresolvable DRBD Split Brain Situation
sect1.para: Although policies to automatically resolve a DRBD split brain situations exist, there are situations which require to be resolved manually. Such a situation is indicated by a Kernel message like:
sect1.screen: kernel: block drbd0: Split-Brain detected, dropping connection!
sect1.para: To resolve the split brain you need to choose a node which data modifications will be discarded. These modifications will be replaced by the data from the healthy node and will not be recoverable, so make sure to choose the right node. If in doubt, make a backup of the node before starting the recovery process. Proceed as follows:

step.para: Put the cluster in maintenance mode:
Check if the chose node is in primary role:
If it is in primary role, stop all services using this resource and switch it to secondary role. If the node already is in secondary role, skip this step.
Check if a node is in state WFConnection by looking at the output of systemctl status drbd.
If the node is in state WFConnection disconnect the resource:
Discard all modifications on the chosen node. This step is irreversible, the modifications on the chosen node will be lost!
If the other (healthy) node is in state WFConnection, synchronization to the chosen node will start automatically. If not, reconnect the healthy node to start the synchronization:
During the synchronization all data modifications on the chosen node will be overwritten with the data from the healthy node.
